byline.contributor: Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad reported from Beirut, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Maher Samaan and Ben Hubbard from Beirut; Somini Sengupta from Amman, Jordan; and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.
byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD, HWAIDA SAAD and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Syrian government is increasingly relying on domestic and foreign militias, primarily Hezbollah, to fight insurgents as high casualties and desertions have whittled official army to half of what it was four years ago; Pres Bashar al-Assad projects confidence, despite notable dismissals and infighting among high-ranking officials; public confidence in government's prospects for victory dwindles.
lead_paragraph: The erosion of the Syrian army, which had struggled to replenish its ranks, is forcing the government to rely on Syrian and foreign militias, especially Hezbollah.

headline.main: An Eroding Syrian Army Points to Strain
headline.print_headline: An Eroding Army Points to Strain in Syria

snippet: The erosion of the Syrian army, which had struggled to replenish its ranks, is forcing the government to rely on Syrian and foreign militias, especially Hezbollah.
